title: Taking this picture could kill you
text:
INSTAGRAM addicts might argue that the photo-sharing and social networking service is a harmless pursuit. 
But that may depend on just how far you go to snap that perfect photo. 
It seems we can’t go more than a few days without reading about a tragic death-by-selfie. 
Just last Thursday a tourist was badly scalded after falling into a bubbling hot geyser in northern Chile. 
The Belgian woman, who is yet to be identified, is in a serious condition with burns over much of her body. The El Tatio geysers in Chile are the third largest geyser field in the world. Flickr Chile Satelital Source: Flickr 
The incident occurred in the northern region of Antofagasta, where thousands of tourists each year visit the Tatio geyser field near the desert town of San Pedro de Atacama. 
Local police said the tourist, who was with her husband, backed into the geyser while trying to take a picture. The El Tatio geysers are famous for shooting scalding columns of water and steam into the air every morning. A Flickr Eduardo Frei Rulz Tagle Source: Flickr 
“She has extreme burns ... over 80 per cent of her body and her life is at risk,” Darwin Acuna, a doctor at a Santiago hospital where the woman was taken for treatment, told AFP. 
The geysers are famous for venting jets of hot water or steam into the air every morning. A tourists gets tries to capture a close-up of the geysers. Flickr Osmar Valdenbenito Source: Flickr 
Her tragic story serves as a warning to other tourists about the dangers of popular tourist destinations. 
Just last week an inquest in Alice Springs into the death of Zoe Woolmer heard that the British tourist “stepped on air” before falling about 15 metres to her death at Kings Canyon in the Northern Territory. Zoe Woolmer. Supplied. 
The 23-year-old was in Australia on a 12-month working visa when she left Sydney for Alice Springs in June last year to take part in a three-day tour of the Watarrka and Uluru-Kata Tjuta national parks with The Rock Tour Company. 
She fell at a lookout known as Kestral Falls, a spot often used for photographs where climbers could make their way down to a rock ledge so that their images would give the impression they were clinging to or falling from the cliff. Kings Canyon. Picture: Zoe Phillips Photography Source: News Limited 
An English tourist was killed at the same ledge in 1996 and there are signs warning people to stay away. 
In September, an Australian tourist died at Norway’s tourist hotspot, Trolltunga cliff. 
Kristi Kafcaloudis, a 24-year-old university student from Queensland, was killed after reportedly losing her balance and falling 700 metres from the “troll’s tongue” ledge while preparing to pose for a photograph. 
The number of people who completed the four-hour trek to Trolltunga has dramatically increased in recent years — from 500 in 2009, to 40,000 last year — and images appearing on social media seem to have raised the bar for dangerous stunts for photos. 
Tourism office Visit Norway has decided to remove some of its pictures featuring tourists posing on the tip of Trolltunga, “in order to not inspire others to pose the same way”. 
Travel Insurance Direct’s Phil Sylvester said while Australia has many regulations to keep us safe, in many foreign countries the onus can be on the individual to keep themselves safe. 
“Australia is often accused of being a nanny state with lots of regulation to try to keep us safe,” he told news.com.au. 
“In many countries the reverse is true — the individual is expected to be responsible for their own safety, so you won’t find warning signs or fences and such. 
“At the very heart of the travel insurance arrangement is an undertaking by us to cover you for unexpected things, and for you to not put yourself needlessly at risk. Stepping over the safety fence at the Grand Canyon to get that shot is breaking that contract ... you’re putting yourself in harm’s way.” 
Here are some other popular spots where tourists go to extreme lengths to get a photo to show their friends and family. Cape Douglas, South Australia 
Also in Australia, a 30-year-old woman died while trying to take a photograph of the rocky shore at Cape Douglas, near Mount Gambier, in 2010. She slipped and fell 50m down the cliff face. Mount Gambier. Picture: Leanna Adams Grand Canyon, Arizona, US 
The Grand Canyon is a spectacular and popular spot, with a dark history. 
In fact, a 2015 report published by The Atlantic City Lab, estimated some 770 people have died at the Grand Canyon since the mid-1800s. “Due to inconsistencies in the record, the real number is probably higher,” City Lab reported. 
Causes of death at the Grand Canyon include accidental falls, suicides, hypothermia, dehydration and even plane crashes, among others. The Grand Canyon National Park. Supplied Machu Picchu 
The ancient city of Machu Picchu lies at the top of the Inca Trail, which has become known as the “hike of death”. 
Unfortunately, that’s because it has claimed lives. Two years ago American tourist Rachel Gian, 26, died after falling into a ravine near the popular tourist spot. It follows the death of 73-year-old Werner Grimpen along the Inca Trail after a section of rocks came loose. 
While there’s no suggestion they were taking photos when they fell, Machu Picchu guides frequently warn people that tourists have plummeted to their deaths — or been severely injured — while trying to take the perfect snap. A view of the zigzag road at Machu Picchu, from Waynapicchu. Supplied Victoria Falls, Africa 
Occasional deaths have been reported here, including a case in 2009 a tour guide was killed after plunging 90m into the falls while trying to rescue a tourist on the edge of the falls. Many tourists pose for photos while very close to the edge. Victoria Falls, Zambia. Supplied
